    <h1 class="text-x-large" id="page-title">
      Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights
    
    
  </h1></div>
</div>

				<div class="x-hwp-container x-hwp-container-px hwp-w-full x-hwp-py-32 x-lg:hwp-py-64 ">
						<div class="hwp-flex-1 hwp-overflow-hidden is-layout-constrained">
									<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-pt-32 lg:hwp-pt-64"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-large is-resized"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="297" src="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg" alt="Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Logo against transparent blue background over trees." class="wp-image-14810" style="width:1103px;height:auto" srcset="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg 1024w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-300x87.jpeg 300w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-768x223.jpeg 768w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1536x445.jpeg 1536w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-2048x594.jpeg 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px"></figure>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p></p>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.</p>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the <a href="https://www.birzeit.edu/en/community-affairs/institutes-centers/institute-community-public-health" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Institute of Community and Public Health</a> at <a href="https://www.birzeit.edu/en" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Birzeit University</a> and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.</p>
</div></div>

        <h2 class="hwp-section-heading__title text-medium">
      Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course
    </h2>
            <div class="hwp-section-heading__description hwp-text-block ">
      In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the <a href="https://www.emro.who.int/opt/news/palestine-social-medicine-course-launched.html">World Health Organization – office for the occupied Palestinian territory</a>. The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.<br><br>In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the <a href="https://www.emro.who.int/opt/news/palestine-social-medicine-course-launched.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">World Health Organization – office for the occupied Palestinian territory</a>. The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.<br><br>A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course <a href="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/10/SMC_Brief-Report_2024_DM_Oct_2024.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">here</a>.<br><br>We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact <a href="mailto:nbahour@hsph.harvard.edu">nbahour@hsph.harvard.edu</a>.
    </div>

  3. Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights

Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights

The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.

The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the at and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.

Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Projects

Find out more arrow_circle_right Recent publications arrow_circle_right

Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course

In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the . The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the . The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course here.We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact .
More information about the course arrow_circle_right

Palestine Health Research Fund

The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis. Please inquire with for further information.

Programming Areas

Knowledge Production

Utilizing a theory of ‘transformational framing,’ the PPHHR seeks to develop new approaches to understanding the health of Palestinians through historical, political, social science lenses. The program also builds upon widely used frameworks in health and human rights to link drivers of Palestinian health to those of similarly impacted populations around the world.

Education

Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.

Community Engagement

The program contributes to the international network of institutions, organizations, and individuals engaged in elucidating the structural determinants of health with a special focus on the frameworks of human rights and structural racism. The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.

Webinars

Please click here to view recent webinars arrow_circle_right

Follow the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights on X .

#  Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights 
![Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Logo against transparent blue background over trees.](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg)
The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.
The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the at and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.
##  Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Projects 
[ Find out more arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/sph-fxb/racial-justice/palestine-program/projects/) [ Recent publications arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/racial-justice/palestine-program/#Recent-Publications-PPHHR)
![Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem seen through arches](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2022/10/Palestine-Rock-Temple-scaled-1.jpg)
##  Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course 
In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the . The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the . The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course [here](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/10/SMC_Brief-Report_2024_DM_Oct_2024.pdf).We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact . 
[ More information about the course arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/racial-justice/palestine-program/palestine-social-medicine-course/)
### Palestine Health Research Fund 
The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. **Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis.** Please inquire with for further information.
![](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Research-Fund.png)
##  Programming Areas 
### Knowledge Production 
Utilizing a theory of ‘transformational framing,’ the PPHHR seeks to develop new approaches to understanding the health of Palestinians through historical, political, social science lenses. The program also builds upon widely used frameworks in health and human rights to link drivers of Palestinian health to those of similarly impacted populations around the world.
![Seated woman speaking to group of four seated students in a hallway at Birzeit University Institute of Community and Public Health](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Knowledge-production.png)
### Education 
Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.
![Man standing and holding microphone speaking to students seated in classroom](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Education.jpeg)
### Community Engagement 
The program contributes to the international network of institutions, organizations, and individuals engaged in elucidating the structural determinants of health with a special focus on the frameworks of human rights and structural racism. The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.
![Group of people listening to man in green polo shirt under black and red arch on the street in Palestine](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-community-engagement.jpeg)
### Webinars 
[ Please click here to view recent webinars arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/palestine-program-webinars/)
![FXB Center for Health and Human Rights logo, Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights logo, The Center for Middle Eastern Studies Harvard University logo, Harvard Divinity School Religion and Public Life - Religion, Conflict, and Peace Initiative logo, Harvard Kennedy School Carr Center for Human Rights Policy. Birzeit University logo. Webinar: Targeting Health: Detention, torture, and attacks on Palestinian healthcare workers. Moderator: A. Kayum Ahmed, PhD, LLM, Program Lead for the Global Health Initiative, Human Rights Watch; Milena Ansari, LLM, Israel and Palestine Assistant Researcher, Human Rights Watch; Muath Alser, Physician, Co-founder and Director, Healthcare Workers Watch; Osaid Alser, MD, MSc \(Oxon\), General Surgery Trainee, Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center. Tuesday, November 19, 2024. 12:00pm EST, 7:00pm EET. Hsph.me/PPHHR-Nov2024. Speaker remarks are based on their own scholarship and experience. As such, they speak for themselves, not Harvard University.](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/11/11.19.24-PPHHR-Targeting-Health-Webinar-v2.jpg)

<div class="hwp-page-title hwp-bg-dark-base">
  <div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px hwp-py-32">
    
    <h1 class="text-x-large" id="page-title">
      Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights
    
    
  </h1></div>
</div>

				<div class="x-hwp-container x-hwp-container-px hwp-w-full x-hwp-py-32 x-lg:hwp-py-64 ">

<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-large is-resized"><img decoding="async" width="1024" height="297" src="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg" alt="Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Logo against transparent blue background over trees." class="wp-image-14810" style="width:1103px;height:auto" srcset="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg 1024w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-300x87.jpeg 300w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-768x223.jpeg 768w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1536x445.jpeg 1536w, https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-2048x594.jpeg 2048w" sizes="(max-width: 1024px) 100vw, 1024px"></figure>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p></p>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.</p>
</div></div>

<div class="hwp-container hwp-container-px"><div class="hwp-text-block">
<p>The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the <a href="https://www.birzeit.edu/en/community-affairs/institutes-centers/institute-community-public-health" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Institute of Community and Public Health</a> at <a href="https://www.birzeit.edu/en" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Birzeit University</a> and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.</p>
</div></div>

        <h2 class="hwp-section-heading__title text-medium">
      Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course
    </h2>
            <div class="hwp-section-heading__description hwp-text-block ">
      In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the <a href="https://www.emro.who.int/opt/news/palestine-social-medicine-course-launched.html">World Health Organization – office for the occupied Palestinian territory</a>. The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.<br><br>In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the <a href="https://www.emro.who.int/opt/news/palestine-social-medicine-course-launched.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">World Health Organization – office for the occupied Palestinian territory</a>. The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.<br><br>A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course <a href="https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/10/SMC_Brief-Report_2024_DM_Oct_2024.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">here</a>.<br><br>We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact <a href="mailto:nbahour@hsph.harvard.edu">nbahour@hsph.harvard.edu</a>.
    </div>

  3. Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights

Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights

The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.

The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the at and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.

Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Projects

Find out more arrow_circle_right Recent publications arrow_circle_right

Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course

In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the . The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the . The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course here.We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact .
More information about the course arrow_circle_right

Palestine Health Research Fund

The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis. Please inquire with for further information.

Programming Areas

Knowledge Production

Utilizing a theory of ‘transformational framing,’ the PPHHR seeks to develop new approaches to understanding the health of Palestinians through historical, political, social science lenses. The program also builds upon widely used frameworks in health and human rights to link drivers of Palestinian health to those of similarly impacted populations around the world.

Education

Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.

Community Engagement

The program contributes to the international network of institutions, organizations, and individuals engaged in elucidating the structural determinants of health with a special focus on the frameworks of human rights and structural racism. The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.

Webinars

Please click here to view recent webinars arrow_circle_right

Follow the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights on X .

#  Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights 
![Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Logo against transparent blue background over trees.](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg)
The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. ##  Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course 
In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the . The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the . The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course [here](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/10/SMC_Brief-Report_2024_DM_Oct_2024.pdf).We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact . 
[ More information about the course arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/racial-justice/palestine-program/palestine-social-medicine-course/)
### Palestine Health Research Fund 
The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. **Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis.** Please inquire with for further information.

##  Programming Areas

Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.

The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.

#  Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights 
![Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Logo against transparent blue background over trees.](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/04/PPHHR-logo-2-scaled-e1681409699516-1024x297.jpeg)
The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights is an academic hub engaging in a broadly collaborative justice and rights-based approach in the study of Palestinian health through knowledge production, education, and multidisciplinary community engagement. Addressing the drivers of health inequities for Palestinians requires a multidisciplinary approach across the fields of public health, human rights, law, politics, history, and the social sciences. The Palestine Program’s cross-disciplinary engagement seeks to produce scholarship aimed at elucidating and addressing the structural determinants of health for Palestinians in the occupied territory, Israel, and the diaspora and supporting the next generation of public health and medical practitioners committed to improving the future of Palestinian health.
The Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights utilizes a decolonial framework in program development, leadership, and engagement. This framework involves surfacing, examining, and working to dismantle power dynamics and structures that perpetuate inequities in knowledge production and dissemination between Global North and Global South institutions. The program launched as a collaboration between the FXB Center and the at and invites interdisciplinary collaboration between academics, researchers, and practitioners from leading academic institutions worldwide.
##  Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Projects 
[ Find out more arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/sph-fxb/racial-justice/palestine-program/projects/) [ Recent publications arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/racial-justice/palestine-program/#Recent-Publications-PPHHR)
![Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem seen through arches](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2022/10/Palestine-Rock-Temple-scaled-1.jpg)
##  Palestine Social Medicine Intensive Summer Course 
In July 2023, the Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights hosted its inaugural Palestine Social Medicine Course at the Institute of Community and Public Health at Birzeit University in partnership with the . The overall objective of the course was to develop critical engagement with and understanding of the social and structural drivers of health in Palestinian society.In August 2024, the program hosted the Second Annual Palestine Social Medicine Course in Amman, Jordan, in collaboration with the . The course’s primary objective is to foster a critical understanding of the social and structural determinants of health within Palestinian society.A total of 28 students from the United States and the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region participated in the course. The U.S.-based participants included students and professionals from fields such as medicine, public health, and anthropology. The MENA cohort included students from Palestine, Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, and Morocco. Read about the 2024 course [here](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/10/SMC_Brief-Report_2024_DM_Oct_2024.pdf).We are currently not accepting applications for the 2025 Palestine Social Medicine Course. If you have any questions, please feel free to contact . 
[ More information about the course arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/racial-justice/palestine-program/palestine-social-medicine-course/)
### Palestine Health Research Fund 
The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. **Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis.** Please inquire with for further information.
![](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Research-Fund.png)
##  Programming Areas 
### Knowledge Production 
Utilizing a theory of ‘transformational framing,’ the PPHHR seeks to develop new approaches to understanding the health of Palestinians through historical, political, social science lenses. The program also builds upon widely used frameworks in health and human rights to link drivers of Palestinian health to those of similarly impacted populations around the world.
![Seated woman speaking to group of four seated students in a hallway at Birzeit University Institute of Community and Public Health](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Knowledge-production.png)
### Education 
Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.
![Man standing and holding microphone speaking to students seated in classroom](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-Education.jpeg)
### Community Engagement 
The program contributes to the international network of institutions, organizations, and individuals engaged in elucidating the structural determinants of health with a special focus on the frameworks of human rights and structural racism. The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.
![Group of people listening to man in green polo shirt under black and red arch on the street in Palestine](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2023/09/PPHHR-community-engagement.jpeg)
### Webinars 
[ Please click here to view recent webinars arrow_circle_right ](https://fxb.harvard.edu/palestine-program-webinars/)
![FXB Center for Health and Human Rights logo, Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights logo, The Center for Middle Eastern Studies Harvard University logo, Harvard Divinity School Religion and Public Life - Religion, Conflict, and Peace Initiative logo, Harvard Kennedy School Carr Center for Human Rights Policy. Birzeit University logo. Webinar: Targeting Health: Detention, torture, and attacks on Palestinian healthcare workers. Moderator: A. Kayum Ahmed, PhD, LLM, Program Lead for the Global Health Initiative, Human Rights Watch; Milena Ansari, LLM, Israel and Palestine Assistant Researcher, Human Rights Watch; Muath Alser, Physician, Co-founder and Director, Healthcare Workers Watch; Osaid Alser, MD, MSc \(Oxon\), General Surgery Trainee, Texas Tech University Health Sciences Center. Tuesday, November 19, 2024. 12:00pm EST, 7:00pm EET. Hsph.me/PPHHR-Nov2024. Speaker remarks are based on their own scholarship and experience. As such, they speak for themselves, not Harvard University.](https://fxb.harvard.edu/files/2024/11/11.19.24-PPHHR-Targeting-Health-Webinar-v2.jpg)

images.alt: Dome of the Rock in Jerusalem seen through arches
images.desc: Palestine Program for Health and Human Rights Projects Find out more arrow_circle_right Recent publications arrow_circle_right

Palestine Health Research Fund The Palestine Health Research Fund supports Birzeit and Harvard students and faculty to undertake research aimed at elucidating the structural and social determinants of health through grant and stipend support. Applications for stipend support are accepted on a rolling basis. Please inquire with for further information.

images.alt: Seated woman speaking to group of four seated students in a hallway at Birzeit University Institute of Community and Public Health
images.desc: Knowledge Production Utilizing a theory of ‘transformational framing,’ the PPHHR seeks to develop new approaches to understanding the health of Palestinians through historical, political, social science lenses. The program also builds upon widely used frameworks in health and human rights to link drivers of Palestinian health to those of similarly impacted populations around the world.

images.alt: Man standing and holding microphone speaking to students seated in classroom
images.desc: Education Education transects the work of the program and seeks to provide opportunities and educate the next generation of student, faculty, and community human rights leaders engaging in work on Palestinian health.

images.alt: Group of people listening to man in green polo shirt under black and red arch on the street in Palestine
images.desc: Community Engagement The program contributes to the international network of institutions, organizations, and individuals engaged in elucidating the structural determinants of health with a special focus on the frameworks of human rights and structural racism. The program works with impacted communities through academic, community, and educational collaboration.
